title: 107_hr2135
content: The "Consumer Privacy Protection Act" is the short title of the Act. The purpose of the Act is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds that people in the United States lack important privacy protections, leading to concerns about misuse of personal information affecting employment, insurance, credit, medical care, and electronic commerce. Privacy protections are crucial for businesses to gain consumer trust, with a high percentage of Internet users worried about unauthorized access to their personal data. This has resulted in significant financial losses for companies due to abandoned e-commerce transactions. The Congress finds that privacy protections are crucial for businesses to gain consumer trust, with significant financial losses for companies due to abandoned e-commerce transactions. In 2000, companies suffered an estimated loss of $12.4 billion. Public officials should take steps to safeguard privacy in the Information Age. The purpose of the Act is to protect personal information and ensure consumer consent is obtained for its use. The Act aims to protect personal information and require consumer consent for its use. The Act aims to protect personal information by limiting disclosure to others without consumer consent. Disclosure must be accompanied by a clear description of the extent and circumstances, and must not exceed the scope of the consumer's prior consent. The Act prohibits information recipients from collecting unnecessary personal information and from refusing transactions based on consent withdrawal, except for specific disclosure purposes. Consumers must have reasonable access to their personal information. Recipient must provide consumers with reasonable access to their personal information. SEC. 4. EXCEPTIONS. Section 3 does not apply to the disclosure of personal information for various specific purposes, such as transaction administration, fraud prevention, debt collection, legal process, law enforcement, and regulatory purposes, among others. SEC. 5 of the Act prohibits the disclosure of personal information in a way that violates the Act, constituting an unfair or deceptive practice. Violating a rule under this Act is also considered a violation of the Federal Trade Commission Act. SEC. 6 provides a safe harbor provision. A person does not violate the Act if they establish, implement, and follow reasonable practices and procedures to prevent violations. They can also follow guidelines issued by a self-regulatory organization or model guidelines issued by the Commission. The Federal Trade Commission must approve or disapprove guidelines proposed by a self-regulatory organization within 90 days of receiving a request, after providing notice and an opportunity for comment. The reasons for any disapproval must be provided in writing. SEC. 7. PRIVATE RIGHT OF ACTION. A consumer can sue in federal or state court to stop violations of this Act and seek damages of at least $1,000 per violation. SEC. 8. ACTIONS BY STATES. Whenever the attorney general of a State believes there is a pattern of violations of the Act, the State can bring a civil action to stop the violations and recover damages for residents. Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over these cases. The courts of the United States have exclusive jurisdiction over civil actions under this section. In a civil action, a permanent or temporary injunction can be granted without bond. The State must notify the Federal Trade Commission before bringing a civil action and provide a copy of the complaint. The Commission has the right to intervene, be heard on all matters, and file petitions for appeal. The Federal Trade Commission has exclusive jurisdiction over civil actions under this Act. During a civil action commenced by the Commission, no State can subsequently bring a civil action against any defendant named in the Commission's complaint for the same violation. SEC. 9. PREEMPTION. This Act and its rules preempt any conflicting State laws. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "information recipient," "consumer," and "personal information," including personally identifiable information like names, addresses, and phone numbers. The Act defines "sensitive personal information" as including Social Security numbers and financial information. It also clarifies that "State" includes any commonwealth, territory, or possession of the United States, and that a violation of the Act includes violation of a rule made under the Act. The Federal Trade Commission must create rules within one year of the Act's enactment, in line with section 553 of title 5, US Code. These rules must be effective within 180 days of publication. The Act, excluding section 11, will come into effect on the same date as the rules under section 11.
